required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Satiating Effects of Isolated Soy Proteins
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of the Satiating Effects of Differentially Processed Isolated Soy Proteins

brief_summary.textblock: Proteins are known to be more satiating than the other macronutrients; however, the type and amount of protein needed to induce a significant effect on satiety (fullness between meals) is sometimes difficult to determine. In this study, 2 differentially processed isolated soy proteins will be tested for satiety using subjective visual analogue scales. The amount of food consumed following intake of the isolated soy proteins will be measured 3 hours after consuming the proteins. The hypothesis is that differentially processed isolated soy proteins will show unique satiety responses.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: Measure subjective satiety using visual analogue scales

secondary_outcome.description: At the end of 3 hours after consuming test diets, measure the amount of food consumed for 30 mins

arm_group.description: 10 grams of the test ISP will be consumed as a dry-blended beverage
20 grams of the test ISP will be consumed as a dry-blended beverage
10 grams of the control ISP will be consumed as a dry-blended beverage
20 grams of the control ISP will be consumed as a dry-blended beverage

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- BMI between 20 and 30 kg/m2
- Age between 18-65y
- Unrestrained eater (score<12)
- Regularly consume 3 meals per day
- Moderate exercise (eg running, aerobics classes, other sports activities) of no more than 7 hours per week
Exclusion Criteria:
- use of drugs that influence carbohydrate or lipid metabolism (eg. hypoglycemic agents, antibiotics taken less than 6 weeks before study entry, glucocorticoids, anti-diarrheal medication, weight loss medication, and anti-diabetic medication)
- presence of any significant disease (eg gastrointestinal diseases, diabetes, a CVD event less than 12 weeks from study entry, current hepatic disease, etc)
- use of special dietary treatments within 4 weeks of study (eg weight loss diet, extremely high or low carbohydrate/protein/fat diet, use of meal replacements more than once a day)
- use of supplements within 1 week of study (does not include vitamin supplements or supplements which are routinely taken and were initiated 4 weeks before the study and which will be continued during the study period)
- restrained eater (score>12)
- weight change (absolute body weight change of â‰¥ 10%) within the previous 6 weeks
- alcohol intake >2 drinks/day
- food allergies of any kind
- swallowing difficulties
- exercising more than 7 hours per week

clinical_study.keyword: obesity, isolated soy protein, satiety, food intake
